markdown_content:
# Cendara University Academic Programs Summary

## Overview

Cendara University offers a comprehensive range of academic programs through its constituent schools and departments. Our commitment to fostering innovation, leadership, and critical inquiry is reflected in the diversity and rigor of our degree offerings. Below is a summary of all degrees, schools, departments, and specialized programs currently available at Cendara University.

---

## Schools and Departments

### 1. School of Arts & Humanities

- **Department of English and Comparative Literature**
- **Department of History**
- **Department of Philosophy**
- **Department of Modern Languages**

### 2. School of Sciences

- **Department of Biology**
- **Department of Chemistry**
- **Department of Physics**
- **Department of Mathematics and Statistics**

### 3. School of Engineering & Technology

- **Department of Computer Science**
- **Department of Mechanical Engineering**
- **Department of Electrical Engineering**
- **Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering**

### 4. School of Social Sciences

- **Department of Psychology**
- **Department of Political Science**
- **Department of Sociology and Anthropology**
- **Department of Economics**

### 5. School of Business

- **Department of Management**
- **Department of Finance and Accounting**
- **Department of Marketing**
- **Department of Entrepreneurship**

### 6. School of Education

- **Department of Curriculum & Instruction**
- **Department of Special Education**
- **Department of Educational Leadership**

### 7. School of Health Sciences

- **Department of Nursing**
- **Department of Public Health**
- **Department of Nutrition and Dietetics**

---

## Degrees Offered

| Degree                            | Schools/Departments                                                                               |
|------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Bachelor of Arts (B.A.)            | English, History, Philosophy, Modern Languages, Psychology, Political Science, Sociology         |
| Bachelor of Science (B.Sc.)        | Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Mathematics, Computer Science, Economics, Environmental Engineering |
| Bachelor of Engineering (B.Eng.)   | Mechanical, Electrical, Civil and Environmental Engineering                                       |
| Bachelor of Business Administration (B.B.A.) | Management, Finance, Marketing, Entrepreneurship                             |
| Bachelor of Education (B.Ed.)      | Curriculum & Instruction, Special Education                                                      |
| Bachelor of Nursing Science (B.N.S.) | Nursing                                                                                          |
| Master of Arts (M.A.)              | English, History, Modern Languages, Philosophy                                                   |
| Master of Science (M.Sc.)          | Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Mathematics, Computer Science, Public Health, Nutrition             |
| Master of Engineering (M.Eng.)     | Mechanical, Electrical, Civil and Environmental Engineering                                      |
| Master of Business Administration (M.B.A.) | Management, Finance, Marketing                                             |
| Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.)       | English, History, Biology, Physics, Computer Science, Psychology, Education, Business            |

---

## Specialized Programs

- **Honors College**: Interdisciplinary honors curriculum for high-achieving undergraduates across all schools.
- **Sustainable Technology Initiative**: Focused track within Engineering on renewable energy and sustainable infrastructure.
- **International Business Concentration**: Specialized track within B.B.A. and M.B.A. integrating global business studies.
- **Undergraduate Research Scholars Program**: Mentoring and research funding for undergraduates in STEM fields.
- **Global Education Exchange**: Semester-abroad and dual-degree programs with partner institutions in Europe and Asia.
- **Teacher Residency Program**: A year-long mentored teaching placement for M.Ed. students in area schools.
- **Health Informatics Certification**: Post-baccalaureate certificate offered through Health Sciences.
- **Environmental Policy Minor**: Interdisciplinary minor drawing on Environmental Engineering, Political Science, and Economics.

---

# Cendara University Program Catalog

## School of Arts & Humanities

### Department of English and Comparative Literature

**B.A. in English**  
A diverse curriculum covering literature, writing, linguistics, and media studies.

**M.A./Ph.D. in English**  
Advanced literary analysis, critical theory, and research methods.

### Department of History

**B.A. in History**  
Courses in world history, American history, historical methods, and public history.

**M.A./Ph.D. in History**  
Emphasis on original research, historiography, and archival studies.

### Department of Philosophy

**B.A./M.A. in Philosophy**  
Training in logic, ethics, epistemology, and the history of philosophy.

---

## School of Sciences

### Department of Biology

**B.Sc. in Biology**  
Concentrations: Molecular Biology, Ecology, Marine Biology

**M.Sc./Ph.D. in Biology**  
Specializations in Genetics, Conservation Biology, and Cell Biology

### Department of Chemistry

**B.Sc. in Chemistry**  
Core curriculum: Organic, Inorganic, Analytical, Physical Chemistry

**M.Sc. in Chemistry**  
Research-based thesis program in advanced chemistry topics

### Department of Mathematics and Statistics

**B.Sc. in Mathematics**  
Pathways: Pure Mathematics, Applied Mathematics, Data Science

**M.Sc. in Mathematics**  
Research in algebra, combinatorics, and mathematical modeling

---

## School of Engineering & Technology

### Department of Computer Science

**B.Sc. in Computer Science**  
Tracks: Software Engineering, Artificial Intelligence, Cybersecurity

**M.Sc./Ph.D. in Computer Science**  
Focus on research, advanced algorithms, machine learning

### Department of Mechanical Engineering

**B.Eng./M.Eng. in Mechanical Engineering**  
Core subjects: Thermodynamics, Mechanics, CAD/CAM, Mechatronics

### Department of Electrical Engineering

**B.Eng./M.Eng. in Electrical Engineering**  
Courses in circuit analysis, signal processing, embedded systems

---

## School of Social Sciences

### Department of Psychology

**B.A./M.Sc./Ph.D. in Psychology**  
Areas of study: Clinical, Developmental, Cognitive, Social Psychology

### Department of Economics

**B.Sc. in Economics**  
Specializations: Macroeconomics, Econometrics, International Economics

**M.Sc. in Economics**  
Advanced microeconomic and macroeconomic theory, applied research

---

## School of Business

### Department of Management

**B.B.A./M.B.A. in Management**  
Entrepreneurship, human resources, operations, and strategic management

### Department of Finance and Accounting

**B.B.A. in Finance**  
Investment analysis, corporate finance, financial markets

---

## School of Education

### Department of Curriculum & Instruction

**B.Ed. in Elementary Education**  
Foundational studies in curriculum development and pedagogy

**M.Ed. in Curriculum & Instruction**  
Advanced curriculum design, instructional theory, classroom technologies

---

## School of Health Sciences

### Department of Nursing

**B.N.S. in Nursing**  
Prepares for registered nurse licensure, clinical placements in partner hospitals

### Department of Public Health

**B.Sc. in Public Health**  
Concentrations: Epidemiology, Health Policy, Community Health

**M.Sc. in Public Health**  
Research in population health, environmental health, health informatics

---

## Additional Academic Opportunities

- **Undergraduate Minors**: Art History, Creative Writing, Environmental Policy, Global Studies, Data Science  
- **Double Majors/Dual Degrees**: Available in select programs with academic advising  
- **Evening & Online Programs**: Business, Computer Science, and Education courses available online and evenings for working professionals

---

For full program details, course descriptions, admissions prerequisites, and application deadlines, please refer to the [Cendara University Academic Catalog](https://catalog.cendara.edu) or contact the Office of Admissions at admissions@cendara.edu.

---

markdown_content:
# Cendara University  
## Department of English and Comparative Literature  
### 2024–2025 Course Catalog

## Undergraduate Courses

### ENGL 101: Introduction to Literature

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Foundational exploration of major genres—poetry, fiction, and drama—from diverse cultures and historical periods. Emphasis on close reading, interpretive strategies, and critical discussion.

**Prerequisites:** None

---

### ENGL 102: Fundamentals of Academic Writing

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Practice in formal writing for a variety of academic disciplines. Topics include thesis development, argumentation, research methods, and citation styles.

**Prerequisites:** None

---

### ENGL 203: British Literature I

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
A survey of British literature from the Anglo-Saxon period through the 18th century, including key texts by Chaucer, Shakespeare, and Milton. Attention to literary traditions, historical contexts, and cultural influence.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 101

---

### ENGL 204: British Literature II

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Continuation of ENGL 203, focusing on Romanticism, Victorian literature, and Modernism. Authors include Wordsworth, Tennyson, Woolf, and Joyce.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 101

---

### ENGL 211: American Literature to 1865

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Examination of major works and authors from colonization through the Civil War, including Native American, African American, and immigrant voices.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 101

---

### ENGL 212: American Literature Since 1865

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
A study of representative American literary works from the late 19th century to the present. Emphasizes realism, modernism, postmodernism, and contemporary trends.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 101

---

### ENGL 220: World Literature in Translation

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Works from outside the British and American traditions, read in English translation. Includes poetry, drama, and prose from Asia, Africa, Latin America, and the Middle East.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 101

---

### ENGL 231: Introduction to Linguistics

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Introduction to the scientific study of language, including phonetics, syntax, morphology, semantics, and language acquisition.

**Prerequisites:** None

---

### ENGL 251: Creative Writing

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Workshop-based introduction to writing poetry, short fiction, and creative nonfiction. Supports development of personal voice and style.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 102 or instructor permission

---

### ENGL 260: Literature and Film

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Explores the relationship between written texts and film adaptations. Comparative analysis of narrative strategies, genre conventions, and cultural contexts.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 101

---

### ENGL 299: Special Topics in English

**Credits:** 1–3  
**Description:**  
Rotating topics of current interest in literature, writing, or linguistics. Recent offerings have included "The Gothic Imagination," "Digital Storytelling," and "Eco-Criticism."

**Prerequisites:** At least one prior ENGL course

---

## Upper-Level Undergraduate and Graduate Courses

### ENGL 301: Shakespeare

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Intensive analysis of selected plays and poetry by William Shakespeare. Focus on themes, language, dramatic structure, and socio-historical context.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 203

---

### ENGL 315: The African Diaspora in Literature

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Study of literary works by writers of the African diaspora, addressing themes of identity, migration, and community. Authors include Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Derek Walcott, and Ta-Nehisi Coates.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 101 or 211

---

### ENGL 332: Advanced Grammar and Style

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Detailed examination of English grammar and stylistic conventions, emphasizing practical application in editing and writing.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 231

---

### ENGL 340: Literary Theory and Criticism

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Survey of major theoretical frameworks, including structuralism, postcolonialism, feminism, and psychoanalytic criticism. Application to selected texts.

**Prerequisites:** Two 200-level ENGL courses

---

### ENGL 350: Writing for Digital Media

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Study and practice of writing for online platforms, including blogs, podcasts, and social media. Attention to audience, ethics, and multimodal storytelling.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 102

---

### ENGL 370: Studies in Modern Poetry

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Exploration of major poets and modern poetic movements from the 20th century to the present. Includes work from Eliot, Plath, Hughes, Bishop, and Heaney.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 203 or 204

---

### ENGL 451: Senior Seminar in English

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Capstone seminar for senior English majors. Students complete independent research projects and present their findings in a public symposium.

**Prerequisites:** Senior standing; completion of at least two 300-level ENGL courses

---

### ENGL 498: Honors Thesis

**Credits:** 6 (over two semesters)  
**Description:**  
Individualized research and thesis writing under faculty supervision on a topic approved by the department.

**Prerequisites:** Invitation to Honors Program; ENGL 340

---

## Graduate Courses

### ENGL 520: Research Methods in Literary Studies

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Fundamentals of advanced research, bibliographical strategies, and theory application in literary study. Preparation for thesis work.

**Prerequisites:** Admission to M.A. or Ph.D. program

---

### ENGL 531: Seminar in Comparative Literature

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Comparative analysis of texts from different literary traditions, periods, or languages. Emphasizes interdisciplinary approaches.

**Prerequisites:** Graduate standing

---

### ENGL 550: Critical Theory

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Close study of key texts in 20th and 21st-century critical theory. Topics include deconstruction, queer theory, new historicism, and more.

**Prerequisites:** ENGL 340 or equivalent

---

### ENGL 571: Pedagogy in English Studies

**Credits:** 3  
**Description:**  
Introduction to theories and practices of teaching composition and literature at the college level. Includes supervised teaching practicum.

**Prerequisites:** Graduate standing

---

### ENGL 598: Directed Reading

**Credits:** 1–3  
**Description:**  
Supervised reading program on a specialized topic not covered in regular courses, developed in consultation with a faculty mentor.

**Prerequisites:** Departmental approval

---

### ENGL 599: Thesis Research

**Credits:** 6 (over two semesters)  
**Description:**  
M.A. and Ph.D. thesis research and writing under supervision of a departmental advisor. Oral defense required.

**Prerequisites:** Completion of coursework and proposal approval

---

**Note:**  
Some courses may be offered only in alternate years or terms. For scheduling and instructor assignments, consult the departmental website or contact the Office of the Registrar.

Some courses may be offered only in alternate years or terms. For scheduling and instructor assignments, consult the departmental website or contact the Office of the Registrar.

markdown_content:
# Cendara University Financial Aid Guide  
*Academic Year 2024–2025*

The Office of Financial Assistance is dedicated to making a Cendara University education accessible and affordable. Cendara offers a range of scholarships, grants, loans, and work-study opportunities to help offset educational expenses outlined in the annual fee structure. This guide details available aid programs and provides step-by-step application instructions.

To contact us:  
**Office of Financial Assistance**  
2nd Floor, Founders Hall  
Email: financial.aid@cendara.edu | Phone: (317) 555-2473

---

## 1. Types of Financial Aid

Cendara University offers the following forms of assistance:

- **Scholarships:** Merit-based, talent-based, and need-based awards that do not require repayment.
- **Grants:** Need-based aid, typically from university, state, or federal sources; no repayment required.
- **Loans:** Borrowed funds that must be repaid with interest; both federal and institutional loans are available.
- **Work-Study:** Part-time campus employment to earn money during the academic year.

Each student may be eligible for a combination of these aid types.

---

## 2. Scholarships

Cendara University proudly awards a variety of scholarships, both automatic and application-based, to exceptional students across disciplines.

### 2.1 Merit Scholarships

| Scholarship Name          | Eligibility                                   | Value per Year    | Renewable   | Special Criteria                            |
|--------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|-------------------|-------------|---------------------------------------------|
| Presidential Scholarship | Incoming first-year undergraduates; top 5% of applicants (GPA ≥ 3.95, SAT ≥ 1450/ACT ≥ 33, or IB 40+) | $18,000           | 4 years     | Leadership & community contribution         |
| Cardinal Scholar Award   | All new undergraduates with strong academics (GPA ≥ 3.6)       | $7,000 – $12,000  | 4 years     | Automatic consideration                     |
| Graduate Dean’s Award   | New graduate students, outstanding prior GPA (≥ 3.85)             | $5,000 – $9,000   | Up to 2 years| Department recommendation required          |
| Provost Transfer Award   | Transfer students (≥ 30 credits, GPA ≥ 3.75)                    | $6,000            | 2 years     |                                             |

### 2.2 Competitive & Special Achievement Scholarships

| Scholarship Name             | Who Can Apply          | Value            | Criteria                                                      |
|-----------------------------|------------------------|------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------|
| Cendara Arts Fellowship      | First-year or transfer | $4,000           | Portfolio review; visual/performing arts majors                |
| Cendara STEM Scholars        | First-year             | $8,000           | Demonstrated excellence in STEM fields; interview required     |
| Global Diversity Scholarship | Int’l & U.S. students  | $5,000–$10,000   | Promoting campus diversity; essay & recommendation required     |
| First-Generation Promise     | First in family to attend college | $3,500         | FAFSA/CSS Profile required; preference for Pell-eligible      |
| Valentina Mateo Leadership Award | All undergraduates | $2,000           | Outstanding leadership/service during prior studies            |

- **Application deadlines**: Most scholarships require fall term applications by February 15; some have additional interview or portfolio dates in March.

### 2.3 Departmental & Donor Scholarships

Each department manages additional awards (ranging: $1,000–$6,000/year), often tied to academic major, talent, or declared area of interest.  
Visit [scholarships.cendara.edu/departments](https://scholarships.cendara.edu/departments) for details and application instructions.

---

## 3. Grants

Cendara administers several need-based grant programs drawn from institutional, federal, and state sources.

| Grant Name                  | Eligibility                | Value per Year        | Application           |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------|----------------------|-----------------------|
| Cendara Access Grant        | Undergrad (full-time); based on demonstrated financial need | $2,000–$8,000         | FAFSA or CSS Profile  |
| Federal Pell Grant          | U.S. citizens/permanent residents; demonstrated high need | Up to $7,395           | FAFSA                 |
| State Opportunity Grant     | Indiana residents (full-time undergrad/grad); need-based | $1,200–$4,500         | FAFSA                 |
| Graduate Tuition Grant      | Graduate students (limited selection)                     | $2,500–$5,000         | FAFSA or separate app |

- **Award amounts** depend on Expected Family Contribution (EFC), cost of attendance, and funding levels.
- All grants are subject to annual review and funding availability.

---

## 4. Loans

Student loans are designed to help cover gaps after scholarships and grants are applied. Repayment with interest is required.

### 4.1 Federal Student Loans (U.S. citizens/permanent residents)

| Loan                          | Annual Borrowing Limit            | Typical Interest Rate | Notes                         |
|-------------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------------|-------------------------------|
| Direct Subsidized Loan        | $3,500–$5,500 (undergrad)         | 5.50%                | Need-based, interest subsidized|
| Direct Unsubsidized Loan      | $2,000–$20,500 (undergrad/grad)   | 5.50%–7.05%          | Interest accrues immediately  |
| Grad PLUS Loan                | Cost of attendance minus aid      | 8.05%                | Credit check required         |
| Parent PLUS Loan              | Parent borrower for undergrads    | 8.05%                | Credit check required         |

### 4.2 Institutional Loan Programs (Domestic & International)

- **Cendara Opportunity Loan**: Up to $7,500/year (Fixed 6.25% interest, deferred repayment until 6 months post-graduation; cosigner required for international students)
- **Short-term Emergency Loan**: Up to $1,200/semester (No interest, payable within 6 months)

**Note:** Loan counseling is required for all new borrowers.

---

## 5. Work-Study Employment

Cendara’s Federal and Institutional Work-Study programs provide part-time, on-campus jobs to assist students in meeting expenses.

- Typical positions: Library assistant, lab tech, campus events, dining hall, research aide
- Hourly pay: $12 – $15 (undergraduate), $14 – $18 (graduate)
- Maximum hours: 15/week during terms

Eligibility depends on need and timely application; indicate work-study interest on the FAFSA or Cendara Application for Aid.

---

## 6. Application Procedures

To receive financial aid, applicants must complete the appropriate forms and follow these steps:

### Step 1: Gather Required Documents

- Student and parent tax returns (prior-prior year, e.g., 2022 for 2024–25)
- W-2s and other income statements
- Bank statements and records of investments
- Social Security numbers or governmental IDs (if applicable)
- Academic transcripts for some merit aid

### Step 2: Complete Applications

| Aid Type             | Required Application(s) | Link / Submission Method                        |
|----------------------|------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
| Federal Aid (U.S.)   | FAFSA                  | [https://studentaid.gov](https://studentaid.gov) (School Code: 036469) |
| Need-Based Aid (Intl)| CSS Profile            | [https://cssprofile.collegeboard.org](https://cssprofile.collegeboard.org) |
| University Scholarships | Cendara Scholarship Portal | [scholarships.cendara.edu/apply](https://scholarships.cendara.edu/apply) |
| Indiana State Grants | FAFSA (by April 15)    | Same as above                                  |
| Graduate Department Awards | Dept. Application   | Contact department directly                     |

### Step 3: Submit Supplemental Materials

- Essays, letters of recommendation, or portfolios as specified for certain scholarships
- Documentation verifying special circumstances (loss of income, medical bills, etc.)
- International students: proof of English proficiency & financial Documents

### Step 4: Meet All Deadlines

- **Priority Deadline:** February 15, 2024 (for maximum consideration)
- Cendara Scholarship Portal: Opens October 1, closes March 1
- FAFSA/CSS Profile: Opens October 1; final deadline May 1
- Department/Graduate Scholarships: Vary by unit (consult website)

### Step 5: Review Aid Offer & Accept

- Cendara’s Office of Financial Assistance will send an “Aid Notification” via email/portal.
- Review your offer, accept/decline individual items online.
- Submit additional documents if requested (tax forms, clarification letters, etc.)

### Step 6: Maintain Eligibility

- Must be enrolled at least half-time each semester (≥ 12 credits undergraduate, ≥ 9 credits graduate unless otherwise stated)
- Maintain Satisfactory Academic Progress (minimum GPA 2.0 undergrad/3.0 grad, 67% completion rate)
- Renew FAFSA or applicable forms each year

---

## 7. Additional Financial Support Resources

- **Outside Scholarships:** Students encouraged to apply for external awards (employers, civic groups, national competitions).
- **Payment Plans:** Flexible semester installment plans available via the Bursar’s Office.
- **Emergency Assistance Fund:** One-time support for unforeseen crises; contact deanofstudents@cendara.edu.

---

## 8. Frequently Asked Questions

**Q: Can I combine multiple scholarships or grants?**  
*A: Yes, but total aid may not exceed direct costs (tuition, fees, room/board). Some awards have restrictions; always check notifications.*

**Q: I missed the deadline. Can I still apply?**  
*A: Late applications are accepted, but funding may be limited. Contact the Office of Financial Assistance for guidance.*

**Q: What if my family’s financial situation has recently changed?**  
*A: Submit a Special Circumstances Appeal form with supporting documentation for re-evaluation of your aid package.*

---

## 9. Contacts & Further Information

- **Office of Financial Assistance:** Founders Hall, 2nd Floor
    - Phone: (317) 555-2473
    - Email: financial.aid@cendara.edu
    - Website: [financialaid.cendara.edu](https://financialaid.cendara.edu)
    - Office Hours: Mon–Fri, 8:30am–5:00pm

- **Scholarships Team:** scholarships@cendara.edu  
- **International Student Support:** iss@cendara.edu  

For policy details or appeals, reference the [Student Financial Assistance Handbook](https://financialaid.cendara.edu/handbook).

---

**Empowering your future, today — Cendara University Financial Assistance**

structure_map_output.text: Cendara University Financial Aid Guide
*Academic Year 2024–2025*

The Office of Financial Assistance is dedicated to making a Cendara University education accessible and affordable. Cendara offers a range of scholarships, grants, loans, and work-study opportunities to help offset educational expenses outlined in the annual fee structure. This guide details available aid programs and provides step-by-step application instructions.

To contact us:  
**Office of Financial Assistance**  
2nd Floor, Founders Hall  
Email: financial.aid@cendara.edu | Phone: (317) 555-2473
1. Types of Financial Aid
Cendara University offers the following forms of assistance:

- **Scholarships:** Merit-based, talent-based, and need-based awards that do not require repayment.
- **Grants:** Need-based aid, typically from university, state, or federal sources; no repayment required.
- **Loans:** Borrowed funds that must be repaid with interest; both federal and institutional loans are available.
- **Work-Study:** Part-time campus employment to earn money during the academic year.
Each student may be eligible for a combination of these aid types.
2. Scholarships
Cendara University proudly awards a variety of scholarships, both automatic and application-based, to exceptional students across disciplines.
2.1 Merit Scholarships

| Scholarship Name          | Eligibility                                   | Value per Year    | Renewable   | Special Criteria                            |
|--------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|-------------------|-------------|---------------------------------------------|
| Presidential Scholarship | Incoming first-year undergraduates; top 5% of applicants (GPA ≥ 3.95, SAT ≥ 1450/ACT ≥ 33, or IB 40+) | $18,000           | 4 years     | Leadership & community contribution         |
| Cardinal Scholar Award   | All new undergraduates with strong academics (GPA ≥ 3.6)       | $7,000 – $12,000  | 4 years     | Automatic consideration                     |
| Graduate Dean’s Award   | New graduate students, outstanding prior GPA (≥ 3.85)             | $5,000 – $9,000   | Up to 2 years| Department recommendation required          |
| Provost Transfer Award   | Transfer students (≥ 30 credits, GPA ≥ 3.75)                    | $6,000            | 2 years     |                                             |
2.2 Competitive & Special Achievement Scholarships

| Scholarship Name             | Who Can Apply          | Value            | Criteria                                                      |
|-----------------------------|------------------------|------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------|
| Cendara Arts Fellowship      | First-year or transfer | $4,000           | Portfolio review; visual/performing arts majors                |
| Cendara STEM Scholars        | First-year             | $8,000           | Demonstrated excellence in STEM fields; interview required     |
| Global Diversity Scholarship | Int’l & U.S. students  | $5,000–$10,000   | Promoting campus diversity; essay & recommendation required     |
| First-Generation Promise     | First in family to attend college | $3,500         | FAFSA/CSS Profile required; preference for Pell-eligible      |
| Valentina Mateo Leadership Award | All undergraduates | $2,000           | Outstanding leadership/service during prior studies            |
- **Application deadlines**: Most scholarships require fall term applications by February 15; some have additional interview or portfolio dates in March.
2.3 Departmental & Donor Scholarships

Each department manages additional awards (ranging: $1,000–$6,000/year), often tied to academic major, talent, or declared area of interest.  
Visit [scholarships.cendara.edu/departments](https://scholarships.cendara.edu/departments) for details and application instructions.
3. Grants
Cendara administers several need-based grant programs drawn from institutional, federal, and state sources.

| Grant Name                  | Eligibility                | Value per Year        | Application           |
|-----------------------------|----------------------------|----------------------|-----------------------|
| Cendara Access Grant        | Undergrad (full-time); based on demonstrated financial need | $2,000–$8,000         | FAFSA or CSS Profile  |
| Federal Pell Grant          | U.S. citizens/permanent residents; demonstrated high need | Up to $7,395           | FAFSA                 |
| State Opportunity Grant     | Indiana residents (full-time undergrad/grad); need-based | $1,200–$4,500         | FAFSA                 |
| Graduate Tuition Grant      | Graduate students (limited selection)                     | $2,500–$5,000         | FAFSA or separate app |

- **Award amounts** depend on Expected Family Contribution (EFC), cost of attendance, and funding levels.
- All grants are subject to annual review and funding availability.
4. Loans
Student loans are designed to help cover gaps after scholarships and grants are applied. Repayment with interest is required.
4.1 Federal Student Loans (U.S. citizens/permanent residents)

| Loan                          | Annual Borrowing Limit            | Typical Interest Rate | Notes                         |
|-------------------------------|-----------------------------------|----------------------|-------------------------------|
| Direct Subsidized Loan        | $3,500–$5,500 (undergrad)         | 5.50%                | Need-based, interest subsidized|
| Direct Unsubsidized Loan      | $2,000–$20,500 (undergrad/grad)   | 5.50%–7.05%          | Interest accrues immediately  |
| Grad PLUS Loan                | Cost of attendance minus aid      | 8.05%                | Credit check required         |
| Parent PLUS Loan              | Parent borrower for undergrads    | 8.05%                | Credit check required         |
4.2 Institutional Loan Programs (Domestic & International)

- **Cendara Opportunity Loan**: Up to $7,500/year (Fixed 6.25% interest, deferred repayment until 6 months post-graduation; cosigner required for international students)
- **Short-term Emergency Loan**: Up to $1,200/semester (No interest, payable within 6 months)
**Note:** Loan counseling is required for all new borrowers.
5. Work-Study Employment
Cendara’s Federal and Institutional Work-Study programs provide part-time, on-campus jobs to assist students in meeting expenses.

- Typical positions: Library assistant, lab tech, campus events, dining hall, research aide
- Hourly pay: $12 – $15 (undergraduate), $14 – $18 (graduate)
- Maximum hours: 15/week during terms
Eligibility depends on need and timely application; indicate work-study interest on the FAFSA or Cendara Application for Aid.
6. Application Procedures
To receive financial aid, applicants must complete the appropriate forms and follow these steps:
Step 1: Gather Required Documents

- Student and parent tax returns (prior-prior year, e.g., 2022 for 2024–25)
- W-2s and other income statements
- Bank statements and records of investments
- Social Security numbers or governmental IDs (if applicable)
- Academic transcripts for some merit aid
Step 2: Complete Applications

| Aid Type             | Required Application(s) | Link / Submission Method                        |
|----------------------|------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
| Federal Aid (U.S.)   | FAFSA                  | [https://studentaid.gov](https://studentaid.gov) (School Code: 036469) |
| Need-Based Aid (Intl)| CSS Profile            | [https://cssprofile.collegeboard.org](https://cssprofile.collegeboard.org) |
| University Scholarships | Cendara Scholarship Portal | [scholarships.cendara.edu/apply](https://scholarships.cendara.edu/apply) |
| Indiana State Grants | FAFSA (by April 15)    | Same as above                                  |
| Graduate Department Awards | Dept. Application   | Contact department directly                     |
Step 3: Submit Supplemental Materials

- Essays, letters of recommendation, or portfolios as specified for certain scholarships
- Documentation verifying special circumstances (loss of income, medical bills, etc.)
- International students: proof of English proficiency & financial Documents
Step 4: Meet All Deadlines

- **Priority Deadline:** February 15, 2024 (for maximum consideration)
- Cendara Scholarship Portal: Opens October 1, closes March 1
- FAFSA/CSS Profile: Opens October 1; final deadline May 1
- Department/Graduate Scholarships: Vary by unit (consult website)
Step 5: Review Aid Offer & Accept

- Cendara’s Office of Financial Assistance will send an “Aid Notification” via email/portal.
- Review your offer, accept/decline individual items online.
- Submit additional documents if requested (tax forms, clarification letters, etc.)
Step 6: Maintain Eligibility

- Must be enrolled at least half-time each semester (≥ 12 credits undergraduate, ≥ 9 credits graduate unless otherwise stated)
- Maintain Satisfactory Academic Progress (minimum GPA 2.0 undergrad/3.0 grad, 67% completion rate)
- Renew FAFSA or applicable forms each year
7. Additional Financial Support Resources

- **Outside Scholarships:** Students encouraged to apply for external awards (employers, civic groups, national competitions).
- **Payment Plans:** Flexible semester installment plans available via the Bursar’s Office.
- **Emergency Assistance Fund:** One-time support for unforeseen crises; contact deanofstudents@cendara.edu.
8. Frequently Asked Questions

**Q: Can I combine multiple scholarships or grants?**  
*A: Yes, but total aid may not exceed direct costs (tuition, fees, room/board). Some awards have restrictions; always check notifications.*

**Q: I missed the deadline. Can I still apply?**  
*A: Late applications are accepted, but funding may be limited. Contact the Office of Financial Assistance for guidance.*

**Q: What if my family’s financial situation has recently changed?**  
*A: Submit a Special Circumstances Appeal form with supporting documentation for re-evaluation of your aid package.*
9. Contacts & Further Information

- **Office of Financial Assistance:** Founders Hall, 2nd Floor
    - Phone: (317) 555-2473
    - Email: financial.aid@cendara.edu
    - Website: [financialaid.cendara.edu](https://financialaid.cendara.edu)
    - Office Hours: Mon–Fri, 8:30am–5:00pm

- **Scholarships Team:** scholarships@cendara.edu  
- **International Student Support:** iss@cendara.edu
For policy details or appeals, reference the [Student Financial Assistance Handbook](https://financialaid.cendara.edu/handbook).
**Empowering your future, today — Cendara University Financial Assistance**

markdown_content:
# Cendara University  
## Awards and Recognition

---

### 2023–2024 University Honors

#### Chancellor’s Award for Excellence in Teaching  
**Recipient:** Dr. Simone L. Marquez  
**Department:** Mathematics  
**Presented on:** May 4, 2024  
**Citation:**  
Dr. Marquez is recognized for distinguished teaching and innovative curriculum development in applied mathematics. Her engaging approach and dedication to student mentorship have significantly improved departmental outcomes.

---

#### Distinguished Alumni Achievement Award  
**Recipient:** Dr. Priyanka Halson (Class of 2005)  
**Field:** Medical Research  
**Presented on:** March 15, 2024  
**Citation:**  
Dr. Halson, Director of Cardiology at Meridian General Hospital, has pioneered advancements in heart disease diagnostics, receiving international acclaim. Her commitment to global health advocacy exemplifies Cendara values.

---

#### Staff Service Recognition  
**Recipient:** Mr. James O. Felix  
**Department:** Facilities & Operations  
**Years of Service:** 25  
**Presented on:** December 10, 2023  
**Citation:**  
Mr. Felix’s long-standing dedication has been vital to campus safety and sustainability initiatives. His efforts have contributed to Cendara attaining a regional Green Campus certification.

---

#### Undergraduate Research Excellence Award  
**Recipient:** Maya Elise Greene  
**Major:** Environmental Science  
**Presented on:** May 2, 2024  
**Citation:**  
Maya’s project on river pollution and restoration in the Cendara Valley garnered publication in the Northeast Ecology Review and shaped local environmental policy recommendations.

---

### 2023 Institutional Achievements

- **Top Regional University Award**  
  Granted by the Eastern Academic Review Board for outstanding academic innovation and student satisfaction.

- **Excellence in Diversity and Inclusion (Gold Level)**  
  Awarded by the National Association for Inclusive Education (NAIE) for Cendara’s “Bridge Horizons” initiative, boosting underrepresented groups in STEM by 35%.

- **Innovative Campus Sustainability Program Award**  
  Recognized by the Green Futures Alliance for the comprehensive “Solar Steps” campus energy overhaul, including solar canopy installations and electric fleet conversion.

---

### Faculty Recognition (2023–2024)

| Name                     | Department          | Award                                      | Organization      | Date           |
|--------------------------|---------------------|---------------------------------------------|-------------------|----------------|
| Dr. Mikhail Valenko      | Urban Studies       | Urban Planning Impact Fellow                | Nat. Planning Inst.| January 2024   |
| Prof. Rita Chen          | Theater Arts        | Outstanding Creative Educator               | State Arts Council| October 2023   |
| Dr. Sarah Oluwatunji     | Biology             | Life Sciences Research Advancement Medal    | BioSociety North  | March 2024     |

---

### Student Achievement Highlights

- **Intercollegiate Ethics Bowl Champions**  
  The Cendara Debate Society triumphed in the Northeast Intercollegiate Ethics Bowl, defeating nine regional universities, March 2024.

- **Meridian Technology Prize Finalist**  
  Team AquaAdapt (Katherine Su, Omar Bedeir, Linh Phan) reached the finals for their development of an affordable portable water purifier, April 2024.

- **First Place, National Short Film Festival**  
  “Reflections of Tomorrow,” directed by senior media studies student Elena DiLuca, won top honors for original screenplay, November 2023.

---

### Community & Partner Recognition

- **Civic Engagement Leadership Certification**  
  Presented by Meridian City Council to Cendara University for sustained community service programming and voter engagement workshops, February 2024.

- **Industry Innovation Award**  
  Awarded jointly by Cendara Technology Consortium and InfoStream Corp. for the “STEM to Success” internship pipeline, March 2024.

---

For additional details on awards and recognition, contact the Office of University Relations at recognition@cendara.edu.

markdown_content:
# Cendara University  
## Department of Nursing  
### B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog

The Bachelor of Nursing Science (B.N.S.) program at Cendara University is designed to prepare students for registered nurse licensure and to excel in modern clinical environments. The curriculum blends rigorous academic coursework with hands-on experience in partner hospitals. 

Below is a comprehensive catalog of undergraduate courses offered by the Department of Nursing. Each listing includes the course title, code, detailed description, prerequisites, and credit hours.

---

## Year 1 Courses

### NURS 101: Foundations of Professional Nursing  
- **Description:**  
  Introduces the core principles, history, and ethical standards of the nursing profession. Emphasizes patient-centered care, communication skills, and professional conduct.
- **Prerequisites:** None  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 111: Human Anatomy & Physiology I  
- **Description:**  
  Focuses on the structural and functional organization of the human body with emphasis on the musculoskeletal, nervous, and cardiovascular systems.
- **Prerequisites:** None  
- **Credit Hours:** 4

---

### NURS 112: Human Anatomy & Physiology II  
- **Description:**  
  Continues NURS 111 with a focus on the respiratory, digestive, urinary, and reproductive systems. Includes laboratory sessions and case studies.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 111  
- **Credit Hours:** 4

---

### NURS 120: Health Assessment  
- **Description:**  
  Offers theoretical and practical foundations in physical assessment techniques, including the use of diagnostic equipment and patient interviewing.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 111 (may be taken concurrently)  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 130: Introduction to Clinical Practice  
- **Description:**  
  Provides supervised clinical experiences in a laboratory and hospital setting. Focus on basic nursing skills such as hygiene, infection control, and patient mobility.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 101, NURS 111  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

## Year 2 Courses

### NURS 210: Microbiology for Nurses  
- **Description:**  
  Explores major concepts of microbiology relevant to nursing, including pathogens, infection control, and the immune response.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 112  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 212: Pharmacology I  
- **Description:**  
  Covers fundamental pharmacological principles, drug classifications, and medication administration safety for entry-level nurses.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 112  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 220: Medical-Surgical Nursing I  
- **Description:**  
  Introduces the care of adults experiencing common medical and surgical health problems. Integrates knowledge across body systems with emphasis on assessment and intervention.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 120, NURS 130  
- **Credit Hours:** 4

---

### NURS 221: Medical-Surgical Nursing II  
- **Description:**  
  Builds on NURS 220 by addressing complex health conditions and advanced intervention techniques. Includes simulation and clinical rotations.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 220  
- **Credit Hours:** 4

---

### NURS 231: Nursing Research & Evidence-Based Practice  
- **Description:**  
  Examines the principles and processes of nursing research. Develops skills in appraising evidence and applying findings to clinical decisions.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 120, NURS 130  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

## Year 3 Courses

### NURS 310: Pediatric Nursing  
- **Description:**  
  Covers nursing care for children and adolescents, including developmental stages, health promotion, and family-centered care.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 220  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 312: Maternity & Women’s Health Nursing  
- **Description:**  
  Examines nursing roles in prenatal, perinatal, and postpartum care. Addresses family planning, newborn assessment, and reproductive health issues.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 319: Pathophysiology  
- **Description:**  
  Detailed study of altered physiological processes in major body systems as related to disease processes encountered in nursing practice.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 112  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 330: Mental Health Nursing  
- **Description:**  
  Focuses on therapeutic communication, psychiatric disorders, and evidence-based interventions in mental health settings.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 340: Community Health Nursing  
- **Description:**  
  Prepares students to employ health promotion and disease prevention strategies, conduct assessments, and plan interventions in community settings.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 231  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

## Year 4 Courses

### NURS 410: Leadership & Management in Nursing  
- **Description:**  
  Explores concepts of leadership, management theory, and interprofessional teamwork in healthcare settings. Includes quality improvement and resource management.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221, Senior Standing  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 420: Advanced Clinical Practicum  
- **Description:**  
  Provides intensive clinical immersion across multiple specialties, including critical care, emergency, and surgical nursing. Students work closely with assigned preceptors in partner hospitals.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221, completion of all previous clinical courses  
- **Credit Hours:** 6

---

### NURS 431: Nursing Ethics & Health Policy  
- **Description:**  
  Studies ethical dilemmas in nursing practice, legal responsibilities, and the impact of health policy on patient care and professional standards.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 231  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 440: Capstone Seminar  
- **Description:**  
  Integrates learning from all previous coursework and clinical experiences. Preparation for the national licensure exam (NCLEX-RN) and transition to professional practice.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 420 (may be taken concurrently)  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

## Elective Courses

### NURS 350: Gerontological Nursing  
- **Description:**  
  Explores the unique healthcare needs and challenges in nursing older adults. Addresses chronic disease management, cognitive decline, and elder care advocacy.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

---

### NURS 355: Nursing Informatics  
- **Description:**  
  Introduces digital health records, data management, and the role of informatics in evidence-based nursing practice.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 231  
- **Credit Hours:** 2

---

### NURS 360: Disaster & Emergency Nursing  
- **Description:**  
  Prepares students to manage nursing care in disaster, crisis, and mass casualty situations. Focuses on triage, crisis intervention, and readiness planning.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221  
- **Credit Hours:** 2

---

For further information on course sequencing, graduation requirements, and departmental policies, please refer to the B.N.S. Student Handbook or contact the Department of Nursing at nursing@cendara.edu.

- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 3 Courses > NURS 312: Maternity & Women’s Health Nursing
- **Description:**  
  Examines nursing roles in prenatal, perinatal, and postpartum care. Addresses family planning, newborn assessment, and reproductive health issues.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 3 Courses > NURS 319: Pathophysiology
- **Description:**  
  Detailed study of altered physiological processes in major body systems as related to disease processes encountered in nursing practice.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 112  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 3 Courses > NURS 330: Mental Health Nursing
- **Description:**  
  Focuses on therapeutic communication, psychiatric disorders, and evidence-based interventions in mental health settings.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 3 Courses > NURS 340: Community Health Nursing
- **Description:**  
  Prepares students to employ health promotion and disease prevention strategies, conduct assessments, and plan interventions in community settings.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 231  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 4 Courses > NURS 410: Leadership & Management in Nursing
- **Description:**  
  Explores concepts of leadership, management theory, and interprofessional teamwork in healthcare settings. Includes quality improvement and resource management.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221, Senior Standing  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 4 Courses > NURS 420: Advanced Clinical Practicum
- **Description:**  
  Provides intensive clinical immersion across multiple specialties, including critical care, emergency, and surgical nursing. Students work closely with assigned preceptors in partner hospitals.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221, completion of all previous clinical courses  
- **Credit Hours:** 6

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 4 Courses > NURS 431: Nursing Ethics & Health Policy
- **Description:**  
  Studies ethical dilemmas in nursing practice, legal responsibilities, and the impact of health policy on patient care and professional standards.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 231  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 4 Courses > NURS 440: Capstone Seminar
- **Description:**  
  Integrates learning from all previous coursework and clinical experiences. Preparation for the national licensure exam (NCLEX-RN) and transition to professional practice.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 420 (may be taken concurrently)  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Elective Courses > NURS 350: Gerontological Nursing
- **Description:**  
  Explores the unique healthcare needs and challenges in nursing older adults. Addresses chronic disease management, cognitive decline, and elder care advocacy.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Elective Courses > NURS 355: Nursing Informatics
- **Description:**  
  Introduces digital health records, data management, and the role of informatics in evidence-based nursing practice.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 231  
- **Credit Hours:** 2

B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Elective Courses > NURS 360: Disaster & Emergency Nursing
- **Description:**  
  Prepares students to manage nursing care in disaster, crisis, and mass casualty situations. Focuses on triage, crisis intervention, and readiness planning.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 221  
- **Credit Hours:** 2
For further information on course sequencing, graduation requirements, and departmental policies, please refer to the B.N.S. Student Handbook or contact the Department of Nursing at nursing@cendara.edu.

Block 1: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog
Below is a comprehensive catalog of undergraduate courses offered by the Department of Nursing. Each listing includes the course title, code, detailed description, prerequisites, and credit hours.

Block 2: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 1 Courses > NURS 101: Foundations of Professional Nursing
- **Description:**  
  Introduces the core principles, history, and ethical standards of the nursing profession. Emphasizes patient-centered care, communication skills, and professional conduct.
- **Prerequisites:** None  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

Block 3: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 1 Courses > NURS 111: Human Anatomy & Physiology I
- **Description:**  
  Focuses on the structural and functional organization of the human body with emphasis on the musculoskeletal, nervous, and cardiovascular systems.
- **Prerequisites:** None  
- **Credit Hours:** 4

Block 4: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 1 Courses > NURS 112: Human Anatomy & Physiology II
- **Description:**  
  Continues NURS 111 with a focus on the respiratory, digestive, urinary, and reproductive systems. Includes laboratory sessions and case studies.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 111  
- **Credit Hours:** 4

Block 5: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 1 Courses > NURS 120: Health Assessment
- **Description:**  
  Offers theoretical and practical foundations in physical assessment techniques, including the use of diagnostic equipment and patient interviewing.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 111 (may be taken concurrently)  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

Block 6: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 1 Courses > NURS 130: Introduction to Clinical Practice
- **Description:**  
  Provides supervised clinical experiences in a laboratory and hospital setting. Focus on basic nursing skills such as hygiene, infection control, and patient mobility.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 101, NURS 111  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

Block 7: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 2 Courses > NURS 210: Microbiology for Nurses
- **Description:**  
  Explores major concepts of microbiology relevant to nursing, including pathogens, infection control, and the immune response.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 112  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

Block 8: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 2 Courses > NURS 212: Pharmacology I
- **Description:**  
  Covers fundamental pharmacological principles, drug classifications, and medication administration safety for entry-level nurses.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 112  
- **Credit Hours:** 3

Block 9: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 2 Courses > NURS 220: Medical-Surgical Nursing I
- **Description:**  
  Introduces the care of adults experiencing common medical and surgical health problems. Integrates knowledge across body systems with emphasis on assessment and intervention.
- **Prerequisites:** NURS 120, NURS 130  
- **Credit Hours:** 4

Block 10: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 2 Courses > NURS 221: Medical-Surgical Nursing II
- **Description:**

- **Prerequisites:** NURS 220  
- **Credit Hours:** 4

Block 11: B.N.S. in Nursing — Course Catalog > Year 2 Courses > NURS 231: Nursing Research & Evidence-Based Practice
